Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Carbaporphyrins, Carbachlorins and Related Conjugated Macrocycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis program is supporting Professor Timothy Lash at Illinois State University to explore the synthesis, characterization, and reactivity of porphyrin-like macrocycles. Porphyrins are large-ring heterocycles which possess many valuable properties and have applications in materials science, catalysis and medicine. Porphyrins are widely distributed in nature as catalytic sites in enzymes. Far less research has been reported on porphyrin-like macrocycles or porphyrinoids even though these systems demonstrate properties that complement those of true porphyrins. This research will lead to more efficient routes to carbaporphyrinoid systems, in which one nitrogen is replaced by carbon, and will also provide access to new classes of porphyrin analogues. These projects will improve our understanding of fundamental chemistry concepts such as aromaticity. The new porphyrinoids may find applications in the preparation of fine chemicals, since metalated derivatives can be used to construct catalysts for chemical synthesis. Broader impacts of this research lie in applications of these new substances and in student training. The target compounds have potential medicinal applications as photosensitizers in photodynamic therapy. These projects provide an excellent environment for training undergraduates and M.S.-level graduate students in the field of organic synthesis. Students will be exposed to the multidisciplinary nature of modern scientific research.

In this research, synthetic routes to novel carbaporphyrins and related porphyrinoids, including "neo-confused" porphyrins, carbachlorins and dicarbaporphyrinoids, will be developed. Further application of the [3 + 1]-variant on the MacDonald reaction will allow the synthesis of porphyrinoids with pyranone, phenalene, pyrene and benz[f]indene units, and these studies will be extended to the preparation of fused carbaporphyrinoid dimers. A new synthetic approach to carbaporphyrinoids will also be developed using carbatripyrrin intermediates. This strategy will allow more direct access to carbaporphyrins, heterocarbaporphyrins and dicarbaporphyrins starting from indene or cyclopentadiene. Carbachlorins have been little studied to date, and new routes to dihydroporphyrinoids will also be developed. Carbachlorins have useful properties in their own right and may also act as precursors to carbaporphyrins. Furthermore, syntheses of adj-dicarbaporphyrins will be investigated using a base catalyzed MacDonald [2 + 2]-approach and attempts will be made to prepare tri- and tetracarbaporphyrinoid systems. The properties of this new collection of macrocycles will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Porphyrins are deeply colored compounds that are widespread in nature and perform many essential biological functions. Indeed, porphyrin derivatives (heme, chlorophylls, etc.) are colloquially known as the Pigments of Life. Porphyrins also have many applications that range from the development of novel optical materials to medicine. In the latter category, porphyrins and related systems have been shown to be superior photosensitizers in the treatment of tumors using photodynamic therapy (PDT). The porphyrin framework is built up from four five-membered pyrrole rings and the macrocycle exhibits strongly aromatic properties that extend over the entire system. Given the importance of this research area, structural analogues of the porphyrins are receiving a considerable amount of attention. Porphyrins have four nitrogens within the macrocyclic core, but related hetero-analogues can be prepared with alternative core atoms. In our studies, structures with one or more carbons within the core have been prioritized for investigation. These carbaporphyrinoids have many unusual properties and form stable organometallic derivatives with catalytically active metals such as palladium and rhodium. 

 

In our studies, the synthesis, characterization and metalation of carbaporphyrins and related systems were investigated. A new route to carbaporphyrins was developed from fulvene precursors that were prepared from inexpensive technical grade indene, and this methodology was further adapted to synthesize related structures with internal oxygen (O), sulfur (S) or selenium (Se) atoms. Porphyrins have four nitrogens within the macrocyclic cavity, while carbaporphyrins have one carbon and three nitrogens in these positions. The fulvene strategy enabled the first syntheses of porphyrin analogues with four different atoms within the core, specifically C-N-S-O and C-N-Se-O, as well as related structures with C-N-O-N, C-N-S-N, C-N-Se-N, C-O-N-O and C-N-O-O cores. These innovations allow the properties of these systems to be fine-tuned. Porphyrinoids with long wavelength absorptions have many potential applications (e.g. as photosensitizers in PDT). Chlorins, reduced forms of the porphyrins, have strong absorptions in this region but related systems have not received very much attention. In order to address this issue, synthetic routes to carbachlorins were developed. As expected these structures showed strong absorptions near 650 nm, a potentially useful region in the longer wavelength region (red) of the visible spectrum. These compounds also readily afforded stable rhodium(I) derivatives. 

 

An alternative approach to modifying the porphyrin framework involves introducing expanded subunits such as benzene, azulene or cycloheptatriene. An efficient synthesis of a dicarbaporphyrinoid system with a benzene and an indene unit replacing two of the usual pyrrole rings was designed. These unusual structures retained some of the aromatic properties associated with porphyrins but underwent unprecedented oxidation reactions with silver(I) acetate. Further extension of porphyrinoid structures was accomplished by introducing a pyrene subunit, which consists of four fused benzene rings, and this system readily formed palladium(II) organometallic complexes. Azulene, a blue colored hydrocarbon with fused five and seven-membered rings, can also be incorporated and the resulting porphyrin analogues are known as azuliporphyrins. In recent studies, selective oxidations with copper(II) salts were demonstrated where an oxygen atom was introduced onto the internal carbon. However, oxidations with silver(I) acetate led to selective ring contractions where the seven-membered ring was converted into a fused six-membered ring (benzene). Tropiporphyrins possess a cycloheptatriene subunit, i.e. a seven-membered ring that is directly inserted into the porphyrin structure. Reaction with palladium(II) acetate led to ring contractions that afforded benzene subunits and selectively generated palladium(II) benziporphyrins. However, when tropiporphyrin was first alkylated with methyl iodide, palladium(II) insertion occurred in the absence of ring contraction. 

 

Expansion or contraction of the porphyrinoid macrocycle also allows the properties of these structures to be modified. Expanded carbaporphyrins were prepared from fulvene intermediates, and a route to contracted azuliporphyrins was developed. Dialdehydes of azulitripyrranes, intermediates that consist of an azulene and two pyrrole units, were cyclized to give azulitriphyrins. Triphyrins differ from porphyrins in that they consist of only three cyclic subunits instead of the usual four. Azulitriphyrins underwent ring contractions in the presence of peroxides to give the first examples of carbatriphyrins. These novel diminutive carbaporphyrinoids are nonplanar but still retain strongly aromatic properties. 

 

The advances made in this area provide access to numerous porphyrin-like systems and give insights into the origin of aromaticity in these systems. The discovery of selective reactions to modify these structures, together with their ability to generate organometallic derivatives that have the potential to act as catalytic systems, further emphasize the significance of these investigations.The research conducted with support from this grant resulted in 26 publications in international research journals and 23 presentations were given at national meetings of the American Chemical Society.

 

This work was carried out under the direction of the PI with undergraduate students and MS-level graduate students. Students were trained to carry out synthetic organic procedures and gain a detailed understanding of spectroscopic techniques. This training has a significant impact on their subsequent careers.
